dt: {bc}kept out of sight or hidden from view

dt.t: … displayed a critical tone toward the justices of their era that combined theoretical dismay with barely {wi}concealed{/wi} contempt.

shortdef: kept out of sight or hidden from view

dt.t: The defendant is accused of attempting to {wi}conceal{/wi} evidence.

pt: {sc}hide{/sc} {sc}conceal{/sc} {sc}screen{/sc} {sc}secrete{/sc} {sc}bury{/sc} mean to withhold or withdraw from sight. {sc}hide{/sc} may or may not suggest intent.
{sc}conceal{/sc} usually does imply intent and often specifically implies a refusal to divulge.
{sc}screen{/sc} implies an interposing of something that prevents discovery.
{sc}secrete{/sc} suggests a depositing in a place unknown to others.
{sc}bury{/sc} implies covering up so as to hide completely.

et: Middle English {it}concelen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}conceler,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}concēlāre,{/it} from {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} + {it}cēlāre{/it} "to hide, keep secret," probably derivative of an unattested lengthened-grade noun formed from the Indo-European verb base {it}*ḱel-{/it} "cover, conceal," whence Latin {it}occulere{/it} "to hide from view, keep secret" (from {it}*ob-cel-{/it}), Old Irish {it}ceilid{/it} "(s/he) hides," Welsh {it}celaf{/it} "(I) hide," Germanic {it}*hel-a-{/it} "hide" (whence Old English, Old Saxon & Old High German {it}helan{/it} "to hide, keep secret")
shortdef: to prevent disclosure or recognition of

dt: {bc}the act or practice of carrying a concealed firearm in public or the legal right to do so

dt.t: Hayes attributed the popularity of {wi}concealed carry{/wi} in suburbia to perceptions of safety …
Gun rights advocates predict more complaints about restrictions on firearms in public places, now that a bill to allow {wi}concealed carry{/wi} without a permit has failed in the Legislature.
… certain areas were excluded for {wi}concealed carry{/wi}, and bars are one of them for obvious reasons.
Who decided that Illinois should have {wi}concealed carry{/wi}?

shortdef: the act or practice of carrying a concealed firearm in public or the legal right to do so —often used before another noun
